{"comments": {"id": 668, "count": 137, "talk_id": 811}, "threadId": 668, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "811", "description": "How many of today's headlines will matter in 100 years? 1000? Kirk Citron's \"Long News\" project collects stories that not only matter today, but will resonate for decades -- even centuries -- to come. At TED2010, he highlights recent headlines with the potential to shape our future.", "event": "TED2010", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Kirk Citron: And now, the real news", "slug": "kirk_citron_and_now_the_real_news", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "687", "slug": "kirk_citron", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Kirk", "lastname": "Citron", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Media expert", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/160430_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Some stories are more important than others.", "whotheyare": "Kirk Citron began his career as a fast-rising advertising executive, but now writes and provides media consultation for select non-profits.", "whylisten": "

Kirk Citron seems to have an innate understanding of all things media. He began his career in advertising at Ogilvy & Mather in New York, but soon started his own agency with Matt Haligman. Citron Haligman Bedecarré landed major clients and was named Adweek’s West Agency of the Year. Citron then transformed the company into AKQA -- a digital advertising agency that has won awards on both sides of the Atlantic with offices around the world.

Today, Citron continues to write and innovate. He is the editor of The Long News, finding news stories that will continue to matter as many as a thousand years from today, and consults for a number of non-profit organizations. He is also the author of the play But Not For Lunch, which has been staged at theaters in Maine, Miami and Pennsylvania.

"https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/160430_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Some stories are more important than others.", "whotheyare": "Kirk Citron began his career as a fast-rising advertising executive, but now writes and provides media consultation for select non-profits.", "whylisten": "

Kirk Citron seems to have an innate understanding of all things media. He began his career in advertising at Ogilvy & Mather in New York, but soon started his own agency with Matt Haligman. Citron Haligman Bedecarré landed major clients and was named Adweek’s West Agency of the Year. Citron then transformed the company into AKQA -- a digital advertising agency that has won awards on both sides of the Atlantic with offices around the world.

Today, Citron continues to write and innovate. He is the editor of The Long News, finding news stories that will continue to matter as many as a thousand years from today, and consults for a number of non-profit organizations. He is also the author of the play But Not For Lunch, which has been staged at theaters in Maine, Miami and Pennsylvania.

author: Kirk_Citron;
title: And now, the real news

aws-transcripts.transcript: we are drowning in news. Reuters alone puts out three and 1/2 1,000,000 news stories a year. That's just one source. My question is, how many of those stories were actually gonna matter in the long run? That's the idea behind the long news. It's a project by the Long Now foundation, which was founded by Ted Stirs, including Kevin Kelly and Stewart Brand. And what we're looking for is news stories that might still matter 50 or 100 or 10,000 years from now. I mean, look at the news. Through that filter, a lot falls by the wayside to take the top stories from the A P this last year. Is this gonna matter in a decade? For this, for this, really? Is this gonna matter in 50 or 100 years? Okay, that was kind of cool. But the top story of this past year was the economy, and I'm just betting that sooner or later, this particular recession is gonna be old news. So what kind of stories might make a difference for the future? Well, let's take science. Uh, someday little robots will go through our bloodstreams, fixing things that someday is already here if you're a mouse. Some recent stories Nana be zap tumors with real bee venom. They're sending genes into the brain. A robot they built that can crawl through the human body. What about resource is how we're gonna feed 9,000,000,000 people. We're having trouble feeding 6,000,000,000 today. As we heard yesterday, there's over 1,000,000,000 people hungry. Britain will starve without genetically modified crops. Bill Gates, fortunately, has bet 1,000,000,000 on AG research. What about global politics? The world's gonna be very different when and if China sets the agenda and they may, they've overtaken. The U. S is the world's biggest car market. They've overtaken. Germany is the largest exporter, and they've started doing DNA tests on kids to choose their careers. We're finding all kinds of ways to push back the limits of what we know Some recent discoveries. There's an ant colony from Argentina that has now spread to every continent but Antarctica. There's a self directed robot scientist that's made a discovery soon. Science may no longer need us, and life may no longer need us either. A micro wakes up after 120,000 years. It seems that with or without us, life will go on. But my pick for the top long news story of this past year was this one. Water found on the moon makes it a lot easier to put a colony up there. And if NASA doesn't do it, China might. Or somebody in this room might write a big check. My point is this. In the long run, some news stories are more important than others.
